messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Lattice Problems Beyond Polynomial Time

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study the complexity of lattice problems in a world where algorithms, reductions, and protocols can run in superpolynomial time. Specifically, we revisit four foundational results in this context—two protocols and two worst-case to average-case reductions. We show how to improve the approximation factor in each result by a factor of roughly n/log⁡n𝑛𝑛\sqrt{n/\log n} when running the protocol or reduction in 2ε​nsuperscript2𝜀𝑛2^{\varepsilon n} time instead of polynomial time, and we show a novel protocol with no polynomial-time analog. Our results are as follows. 1. We show a worst-case to average-case reduction proving that secret-key cryptography (specifically, collision-resistant hash functions) exists if the (decision version of the) Shortest Vector Problem (SVP) cannot be approximated to within a factor of O~​(n)~𝑂𝑛\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{n}) in 2ε​nsuperscript2𝜀𝑛2^{\varepsilon n} time for any constant ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. This extends to our setting Ajtai’s celebrated polynomial-time reduction for the Short Integer Solutions problem (SIS) [STOC, 1996], which showed (after improvements by Micciancio and Regev [FOCS, 2004; and SIAM J. Computing, 2007]) that secret-key cryptography exists if SVP cannot be approximated to within a factor of O~​(n)~𝑂𝑛\widetilde{O}(n) in polynomial time. 2. We show another worst-case to average-case reduction proving that public-key cryptography exists if SVP cannot be approximated to within a factor of O~​(n)~𝑂𝑛\widetilde{O}(n) in 2ε​nsuperscript2𝜀𝑛2^{\varepsilon n} time. This extends Regev’s celebrated polynomial-time reduction for the Learning with Errors problem (LWE) [STOC, 2005; and J. ACM, 2009], which achieved an approximation factor of O~​(n1.5)~𝑂superscript𝑛1.5\widetilde{O}(n^{1.5}). In fact, Regev’s reduction is quantum, but we prove our result under a classical reduction, generalizing Peikert’s polynomial-time classical reduction [STOC, 2009], which achieved an approximation factor of O~​(n2)~𝑂superscript𝑛2\widetilde{O}(n^{2}). 3. We show that the (decision version of the) Closest Vector Problem (CVP) with a constant approximation factor has a 𝖼𝗈𝖠𝖬𝖼𝗈𝖠𝖬\mathsf{coAM} protocol with a 2ε​nsuperscript2𝜀𝑛2^{\varepsilon n}-time verifier. This generalizes the celebrated polynomial-time protocol due to Goldreich and Goldwasser [STOC 1998; and J. Comp. Syst. Sci., 2000]. It follows that the recent series of 2ε​nsuperscript2𝜀𝑛2^{\varepsilon n}-time and even 2(1−ε)​nsuperscript21𝜀𝑛2^{(1-\varepsilon)n}-time hardness results for CVP cannot be extended to large constant approximation factors γ𝛾\gamma unless AMETH is false. We also rule out 2(1−ε)​nsuperscript21𝜀𝑛2^{(1-\varepsilon)n}-time lower bounds for any constant approximation factor γ>2𝛾2\gamma>\sqrt{2}, under plausible complexity-theoretic assumptions. (These results also extend to arbitrary norms, with different constants.) 4. We show that O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\sqrt{\log n})-approximate SVP has a 𝖼𝗈𝖭𝖳𝖨𝖬𝖤𝖼𝗈𝖭𝖳𝖨𝖬𝖤\mathsf{coNTIME} protocol with a 2ε​nsuperscript2𝜀𝑛2^{\varepsilon n}-time verifier. Here, the analogous (also celebrated!) polynomial-time result is due to Aharonov and Regev [FOCS, 2005; and J. ACM, 2005], who showed a polynomial-time protocol achieving an approximation factor of n𝑛\sqrt{n}. This result implies similar barriers to hardness, with a larger approximation factor under a weaker complexity-theoretic conjectures (as does the next result). 5. Finally, we give a novel 𝖼𝗈𝖬𝖠𝖼𝗈𝖬𝖠\mathsf{coMA} protocol for constant-factor-approximate CVP with a 2ε​nsuperscript2𝜀𝑛2^{\varepsilon n}-time verifier. Unlike our other results, this protocol has no known analog in the polynomial-time regime. All of the results described above are special cases of more general theorems that achieve time-approximation factor tradeoffs. In particular, the tradeoffs for the first four results smoothly interpolate from the polynomial-time results in prior work to our new results in the exponential-time world.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "CRYSTALS-Kyber (version 3.02) – Submission to round 3 of the NIST post-quantum project",
        "Fine-grained hardness of CVP(P)—Everything that we can prove (and nothing else)",
        "A note on the concrete hardness of the shortest independent vector in lattices",
        "Improved Merlin-Arthur protocols for central problems in fine-grained complexity",
        "Solving the Shortest Vector Problem in 2nsuperscript2𝑛2^{n} time via discrete Gaussian sampling",
        "Generating hard instances of lattice problems",
        "The Shortest Vector Problem in L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} is NP-hard for randomized reductions",
        "A 2n/2superscript2𝑛22^{n/2}-time algorithm for n𝑛\\sqrt{n}-SVP and n𝑛\\sqrt{n}-Hermite SVP, and an improved time-approximation tradeoff for (H)SVP",
        "Lattice problems in NP ∩\\cap coNP",
        "(Gap/S)ETH hardness of SVP",
        "New bounds in some transference theorems in the geometry of numbers",
        "Hypercontractivity, sum-of-squares proofs, and their applications",
        "Lattice problems in general norms: Algorithms with explicit constants, dimension-preserving reductions, and more",
        "The Complexity of the Shortest Vector Problem",
        "Polynomial formulations as a barrier for reduction-based hardness proofs",
        "On the quantitative hardness of CVP",
        "Classical hardness of Learning with Errors",
        "Arthur-Merlin games: A randomized proof system, and a hierarchy of complexity classes",
        "Improved hardness of BDD and SVP under Gap-(S)ETH",
        "On the hardness of average-case k𝑘k-SUM",
        "Nondeterministic extensions of the Strong Exponential Time Hypothesis and consequences for non-reducibility",
        "Approximating the SVP to within a factor (1+1/dimϵ)11superscriptdimitalic-ϵ(1+1/\\mathrm{dim}^{\\epsilon}) is NP-hard under randomized reductions",
        "A random polynomial-time algorithm for approximating the volume of convex bodies",
        "Approximating CVP to within almost-polynomial factors is NP-hard",
        "Some elementary inequalities relating to the gamma and incomplete gamma function",
        "On the limits of nonapproximability of lattice problems",
        "Collision-Free Hashing from Lattice Problems",
        "Approximating shortest lattice vectors is not harder than approximating closest lattice vectors",
        "Finding short lattice vectors within Mordell’s inequality",
        "Trapdoors for hard lattices and new cryptographic constructions",
        "Private coins versus public coins in interactive proof systems",
        "Tensor-based hardness of the Shortest Vector Problem to within almost polynomial factors",
        "The complexity of k𝑘k-SAT",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Local reductions",
        "Hardness of approximating the Shortest Vector Problem in lattices",
        "Finding the closest lattice vector when it’s unusually close",
        "Concise formulas for the area and volume of a hyperspherical cap",
        "Factoring polynomials with rational coefficients",
        "On Bounded Distance Decoding, unique shortest vectors, and the Minimum Distance Problem",
        "The Shortest Vector Problem is NP-hard to approximate to within some constant",
        "Trapdoors for lattices: Simpler, tighter, faster, smaller",
        "Hardness of SIS and LWE with small parameters",
        "Worst-case to average-case reductions based on Gaussian measures",
        "Selected algorithms 2022 - Post-Quantum Cryptography",
        "Public-key cryptosystems from the worst-case Shortest Vector Problem",
        "A decade of lattice cryptography",
        "Pseudorandomness of Ring-LWE for any ring and modulus",
        "On lattices, learning with errors, random linear codes, and cryptography",
        "A hierarchy of polynomial time lattice basis reduction algorithms",
        "Another NP-complete problem and the complexity of computing short vectors in a lattice",
        "On some fine-grained questions in algorithms and complexity",
        "Strong ETH breaks with Merlin and Arthur: Short non-interactive proofs of batch evaluation",
        "Personal communication"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Lattice Problems Beyond Polynomial Time, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
